Gonggi (Korean: ê³µê¸°, IPA: [koËÅ‹É¡i]) is a popular Korean children's game that is traditionally played using five or more small grape-sized pebbles. Nowadays, children buy colourful plastic stones instead of finding pebbles. It can be played alone or with friends. The stones are called gonggitdol (ê³µê¹ƒëŒ. Since only a few stones and a flat surface are needed for play, the game can be played by anyone almost anywhere. An equivalent game also exists in Nepal and is known as 'gatti'.

The game is also called Jjagebatgi in North Gyeongsang Province, Salgu in South Gyeongsang Province, and Datjjakgeoli in South Jeolla Province.

Gameplay
The game generally begins with each player tossing the stones from the palm of their hand into the air. While airborne, the player switches their hand backside up. The gonggi stones are then caught on the back of the hand. The person with the leading amount plays first.

How to play gonggi
Level 1: The stones are thrown on the playing surface and the player picks a stone to throw up in the air. While airborne, the player picks up one stone on the playing surface. Then, the player catches the stone. These steps are repeated until all the stones have been caught.
Level 2: The stones are thrown on the playing surface again. However, at this level, the player picks up the stones two at a time.
Level 3: The stones are thrown on the playing surface. The stones are picked up once in a cluster of three, and the other in the amount of one.
Level 4: The player throws one stone in the air, places the others on the surface, and catches the airborne stone. Then the player tosses the same stone again, but this time, picks up the four clustered stones on the playing surface and catches the airborne stone.
Level 5: The player tosses the stones from the palm of their hand into the air. While airborne, the player switches his hand backside up. The stones are then caught on the back of the hand. Then, the player throws the stones in the air and catches them. The number of stones caught amount to the score. There are various tricks in this phase. Some examples are "The Dragon" and "The Clap–Toss". However, such ostentations are not allowed in official game play.

Various tricks in Level 5
Dragon
While the stones are airborne, the player switches their hand backside up, catches several stones, switches their hand backside down, and catches the stones that are left over.

Clap Toss
While the stones are airborne, the player claps their hand before catching the stones.

Both “dragon” and “clap-toss” gives the player twice the score; twice the number of stones.

—description from wikipedia

Name: Puzzelpost: Het Medusa rapport
Description:
The Medusa report is part 2 of the trilogy "Het spoor van Abigail" (Abigails trail). Just like in part 1, you are asked by Helena Boekanier to help her investigate clues on the whereabouts of her missing sister Abigail. While doing so, you learn more about the family history of the Boekanier sisters.

The game works the same as part 1. You first receive a letter from Helena by mail, asking you for your help. A few days later a package arrives by mail with a report made by Abigail, Helena's sister. You have to deciper the clues to find the current location of Abigail. When you succeeded in doing so, you can upload it to Helena on a website to find out if you have the correct solution.

The Medusa report is an escape game. Solve puzzles, find hidden clues and turn everything upside down to find the clues to solve the mystery.

Name: Dragons: Das grosse Drachenrennen
Description:
Berk's Dragon Riders organize a big dragon flying contest: who has tamed and trained his dragon the best and will win the exciting race? Hiccup on Toothless? Astrid on Stormfly? Fishlegs on Meatlug? Or Snotlout on Hookfang?
With great skill and dice luck, you can bring your favorite to victory.
The goal of the game is to bring your own favorite to the finish first.
—description from the publisher

Place every dragon on start. Every player take a dragon card and hide it from the others. Ommly you know your favorite. Everybody take a dice.place the dice board in the bottom of the box. The players have to roll the dice into the box, one after another. The fields on the dice board are assigned to the 4 dragons. Move the dragons with the dice points ont fiels. If a dragon hits a black field, he has to go 3 fields back. The game ends, when a dragon reached the finish. Winner is the player with his dragon in front...
—user summary

Name: Warhammer Underworlds: Nightvault – Power Unbound
Description:
Take your decks to the next level with 60 new cards for Warhammer Underworlds, consisting of 20 gambit cards and 20 upgrade cards. These include 3 new cards for each of the 8 Nightvault warbands and 36 new universal cards.

—description from the publisher

Name: Pride of Lions (Second Edition)
Description:
This 122 page ruleset seeks to provide a fast and fun game of fantasy mass combat. It is the designer’s belief that the best games result from a combination of simple rules mechanics and the opportunity for the players to make many decisions.

In Pride of Lions the role of each player is that of the commanding general of the army or warlord of the horde. Magic, and the courage and skills of individual heroes, can affect the game, but the outcome of the battle will depend mainly on the clash of large units of common fighters operating under the general’s orders.

Each turn begins with players issuing orders to eligible units by laying inverted movement chits behind each unit. After a magic phase, which can result in a unit’s orders being changed involuntarily or randomly, all orders are revealed and movement is conducted simultaneously by all sides but in a strict sequence, with the most aggressive movement (charges) coming first and skirmishers going last. Both melee combat and missile fire are conducted through opposed die rolls, using dice of various sizes from D4s to D24’s, with the difference between the die rolls determining the outcome. Factors such as terrain, magic, special weapons and tactics, and leadership and heroism by characters all affect the game either through the movement chits or the die rolls.

WHY A SECOND EDITION? HOW IS THIS ONE DIFFERENT? We have a LOT more experience of gaming with these rules now, and 2nd edition reflects lessons learned. There are numerous tweaks, as well as places where a longer explanation seemed necessary for clarity. There are lots of photos, partly to show off our miniatures but also as examples of play. And there are some substantial changes:


     The point system is completely revised, with much greater detail, and applies now to characters as well as to units.
     Dwarven rune magic is much more detailed.
     Godfearers’ “magic” – prayer and spiritual gifts – is also far more detailed and extensive.
     Spirits are developed further.
     There are more and longer generic army lists and spell lists.
     And the movement sequence of air units is better.


—description from the designer

Name: Retribution
Description:
Retribution is a combat strategy game in which each player is attempting to completely clear the battlefield of the other players units. (Exception: if played with the unit, King, the game ends when he is killed)

Setup
Players will collectively or randomly choose 10 units to play with this game. Each player has the same 10 units in thier army but with a dividing wall between them they place their units onto the board in any fashion that they choose. Then the dividing wall is taken down.

Game Play
Players then take turns activating two units each turn trying to decimate the others army. Each unit is unique in its abilities, attack, movement, and health. Although each player starts with the same army, every time one of your units is killed you get to upgrade one of your living units to its advanced version. This freedom to advance the units as you choose along with the 18+ unique units that the players have to choose from to play with gives the game incredible replay value!

—description from the designer

Name: Sing That Word
Description:
Sing That Word is the card game for people who love music.
Even though Sing That Word involves singing, you don't have to be a good singer to be good at the game. You simply have to know songs and song lyrics!

Gameplay in a nutshell: Draw a WORD card from the deck, and then take turns singing song lyrics that contain that WORD. If you successfully sing a lyric, you get a MIC card. The person with the most MIC cards at the end of the round wins the WORD card and the points associated with it (1, 2, or 3 points). The first to 7 points wins the game.

It doesn't matter what genre(s) of music you like because the WORD cards in the deck were compiled based on their frequency of use across all popular genres. We will eventually release genre-specific expansion decks that contain WORD cards that are more common to that genre. (Rap, Country, Metal, Religious, etc). Extremely basic words like "the" and "I" aren't included in the deck.

There are also variations of the game including Rapid Fire Mode, Kanye Mode, and Rap Battle that are described on the included RULES cards.

—description from the publisher

Name: BattleTech: Clan Invasion
Description:
ARMOR UP!

In 3050, the true heirs of the lost Star League thunder forth from the depths of the far Periphery and carve deep into the quarreling Successor States. As the Clan juggernaut rolls across the coreward realms of the Inner Sphere, the House Lords scramble to shore up their defenses and devise some way to halt the invaders.

The Clan spear is aimed at the heart of human-occupied space. Do you possess the bold tactics and heroic courage to defeat warriors trained from birth to conquer? Or will you uphold Kerensky’s dream to cast aside the squabbling lords of the Inner Sphere and reignite the flame of the Star League?

BattleTech is the world’s greatest armored combat game, and now you can add the Clans! Inside this box you’ll discover epic clashes, dynamic characters, and a myriad of gaming experiences for any type of player: miniatures to RPG play, hobby painting to fiction, and beyond.

Clan Invasion includes everything you need to add Clans to your table.

—description from the publisher

Battletech: Clan Invasion include the following items:

• Battletech: Clan Invasion rulebook
• Battletech: Clan Invasion primer
• A 24 page Book of record sheets
• Battletech: Inner Sphere 3025/3052 double sided map
• A tables quick-reference card
• A sheet of cardboard punch outs including Mechs & Terrain Hexes
• The Bonds of Battle Novella
• Hilltops #1 mapsheet
• Rolling Hills #2 mapsheet
• 2 Six-sided dice
• A deck of pilot cards
• 7 High-quality miniatures (Grendel, Timberwolf, Executioner, Nove, Adder, 2 bases of Clan Elementals)

Name: Extinction
Description:
Extinction is a dinosaur battle royale card game where you must protect the last dinosaur eggs of your species. Build your herd of dinosaurs and send them to destroy your friends' nest before they get to yours. Defend yourself against rival herds with well timed Triceratops shields, redirect damage with an Ankylosaurus tail whip, or just completely wipe out your friend's herd with a meteor strike!

Each player starts with 4 cards, 6 Dino eggs (Life Points), and a Herbivore Habitat. Start your turn by drawing 2 cards from the Draw Pile, then choose up to 3 cards to play before ending your turn. To survive Extinction, you'll want to build an army of Dinos. You can play 2 types of egg-smashing Dinos: Herbivores and Carnivores. Since you start with a Herbivore Habitat, you are free to play Herbivore Dinos on your turn. If you're lucky to draw a Carnivore Habitat, you'll be able to cause more destruction upon your opponents with your Carnviore Dinos!

All Dinos start as Hatchlings that deal baby damage to opponents. If you want real egg-crushers that deal even more damage, just feed them food! Food can be used in two ways: to grow Hatchlings and to fend off Dino attacks! Managing your food can make or break your chances of survival, so plan wisely.

When it comes down to the end, there can only be one person to survive Extinction. This game forces you to test your friendships. Will you ally with your best friend or cold-heartedly wipe them out? Do whatever it takes to be the last one standing and earn the righteous title of Sole Survivor of Extinction.

—description from the designer

Name: Siege Songs: Battle of Xuzhou
Description:
åœåŸŽæ¥šæ­Œï¼šæŠ—æˆ°ä¹‹å¾å·žæœƒæˆ° ("Siege Songs: Battle of Xuzhou") is a two-player board wargame that simulates the battle of Xuzhou, Dec. 26, 1937 to June. 9, 1938. "Siege Songs" is the second game in the War of Resistance series.

Each turn represents 1 week and each hex is about 10-12 km across. One player commands the Imperial Japanese Army ï¼ˆå¤§æ—¥æœ¬å¸åœ‹é™¸è»ï¼‰ and the other player commands the National Revolutionary Army ï¼ˆåœ‹æ°‘é©å‘½è»ï¼‰.

In Siege Songs, each player uses operation points to activate Army HQ to lead combat units to move, barrage, combat. In each turn, each player draws tactic markers respectively and roll for initiative. The units include infantry, artillery, cavalry, and tank, etc. The NRA side needs to defend Taieruang and Xuzhou in different scenarios to win the game.

The components includes two 22*34 inches map and 3 5/9 inch die-cut counter boards.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players
Series: War of Resistance (Formosa Force Games)

Name: Constellations Roll & Write
Description:
Equipped with a pencil and a galaxy sheet, all players use results from a dice roll to create constellations (a group of stars). Each player attempts to place the numbers in their galaxy in the best possible way and to make wise use of power-ups to score the most points.
Everyone plays at the same time!

—description from the designer

Name: Vast: The Haunted Hallways
Description:
Vex your opponents with the Shadow Paladin, a damned monster shackled by misfortune, who works to contort the rooms of the Manor into a labyrinth of his own design. Follow the adventures of the Armored Knight as she ventures once again to fight new foes.

The Haunted Hallways introduces two new roles: the Shadow Paladin and Armored Knight. New skeletons with unique powers and gear appear, nearly doubling their strategic options. Gain over forty detailed plastic miniatures, including force walls, treasures, eggs, and webs. Add replayability with Cross-Compatibility rules for using each role in Vast: The Crystal Caverns.

Name: Häkkerite lahing
Description:
Players as a two teams take roles of usual computer-users who fight against evil hackers. 
In his turn player answers trivia-questions about this theme and if answered correctly gets the card for defence for his computer. Then he rolls the hacker-dice which show the target roles. You can use Your aquired trivia-cards for cleaning Your computers.
Team who cleans first his computers wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Medieval Pong: Les Sorts-Bocks
Description:
The Sorts-Bocks are a set of 3 coasters. They represent 3 new special events.
During game set up, place the Sorts-Bocks next to each other on the table. Use as many as you want.
The gameplay remains unchanged with the exeptions of the following rule:
When a tower is distroyed and placed on the box, its owner check if this action starts a new floor. If it does not, nothing happens. But if it does, before activating the caracter power, the player can choose one or more of the available Sorts-Block and put it/them in play.
The 3 coasters are:

. The pit: cancel the throw 
. The wall: forces a player to place it vertically between two of his towers
. The bridge: forces a player to place it horizontally between two of his towers

French edition found in Plato Magazine 118

Name: SAIBOU
Description:
SAIBOU is the Japanese word for “cell”. Your goal is simple - create a culture of 9 cell cards in a 3x3 group before your opponents can! Use  versatile  Stem Cells and Macrophages to fill in gaps and protect yourself, but watch out! Other players can use nasty Bacteria and Virus cards to infect your cells and eat them!

Whether you play carefully or care-free, the luck of the draw and the other players will shake things up for sure!

Part card game, part puzzle, all fun! Quickest games played with two players, but can be played by up to four.
The cards in SAIBOU are deliberately designed with no text, so that anyone can be taught to play by example.

—description from the designer

Name: Composure
Description:
Composure is an adult card game to challenge your relationships.

Each card asks you to take a position on a challenging question or scenario.  Many of the cards are person.  Topics include sex, politics, race, brutality, stereotypes, etc.

Players use their cards to challenge others at the table.  People that can keep their composure while discussing the cards, earn chips.  The player with the most chips is the winner.

Name: Son of Doctor Esker's Notebook
Description:
Doctor Esker has vanished, leaving behind only a mysterious book full of puzzles written in his own hand. Nobody has cracked his cryptic codes yet. Are you up to the challenge?

The game provides a deck of 74 cards which contain ten devious puzzles to solve. You can play through the puzzles solo or together with family and friends. Great for a party, a game night, or a lazy afternoon.

Each puzzle is composed of a set of cards. You can solve the puzzle by reading, comparing, arranging and pondering the messages, drawings, and artwork on the cards. Solving the puzzle reveals a sequence of numbers. When you think you’ve got it, gather the solution cards corresponding to the number sequence and flip them. If you see a message or image, you’ve solved the puzzle. Persevere to the end and receive Dr. Esker's greatest praise and a clue to his story.

Son of Doctor Esker's Notebook is the first sequel to Doctor Esker's Notebook. It is a stand-alone game. You do not need to have played Doctor Esker's Notebook to play this game, and you can play them in any order without any issues.

-description from designer

Name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game – Revelations
Description:
Scarlet Witch, Quicksilver, and War Machine have finally emerged from the shadows. But the Avengers are tested as never before when dark Revelations force them to question everything they know.  The Mandarin manipulates secrets to turn Avenger against Avenger and transforming schemes of deception and corruption make it hard to tell good and evil apart.

Scarlet Witch’s fragile sanity cracks, warping the world into the House of M. Soon the Heroes are haunted by dark memories of tragedy that even Quicksilver’s speed can’t escape. Daring to hope, the Avengers prepare their incredible powers for a desperate last stand.

The 19th expansion for Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game. This requires a Core Set like Legendary or Legendary: Villains to play.

Game Contents
Rules insert and 200 cards:
• 9 New Heroes of 14 cards each
(Each Hero has 1 rare, 3 uncommons, 5 of one common, and 5 of another common)
• 4 New Villain Groups of 8 cards each
• 2 New Henchman Groups of 10 cards each
• 3 New Double-Sided Epic Masterminds
(Each has 1 Mastermind card and 4 Mastermind Tactic cards)
• 4 New Double-Sided Transforming Schemes
• 3 New Special Bystander types (1 copy each)

-description from publisher

Name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game – S.H.I.E.L.D.
Description:
The paramilitary espionage agency S.H.I.E.L.D. guards Earth from criminals, terrorists, and supervillains alike. Formally the Strategic Hazard Intervention Espionage Logistics Division, the Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. are the best of best. They complete reconnaissance, spying, and combat missions that no other agency can handle.

A strict hierarchy of S.H.I.E.L.D. Levels ensures that only the top agents ever know about the organization’s most secret resources, training, and plans. But S.H.I.E.L.D.’s obsession with secrecy has opened a fatal flaw. The terrorist organization Hydra has snaked its way deep into the S.H.I.E.L.D. hierarchy, corrupting the agency from within. Hydra issues sinister plots and missions that S.H.I.E.L.D. agents complete without question. Now the rivalry has finally come to a head, as double and triple agents betray each other time and again, and the agents’ true loyalty will finally be revealed.

The 20th expansion for Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game brings new keywords, new adapting Masterminds and a new card type - Special S.H.I.E.L.D. Officers!

This needs a core set like Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game or Legendary: Villains to play.

Game Contents
Rules insert and 100 cards:
• 4 New Heroes of 14 cards each (Each Hero has 1 rare, 3 uncommons, 5 of one common, and 5 of another common)
• 2 New Villain Groups of 8 cards each
• 2 New Adapting Masterminds (Each has no Mastermind card – just 4 Mastermind Tactic cards)
• 4 New Schemes
• 16 New Special S.H.I.E.L.D. Officers (2 each of 8 types)

-description from publisher

Name: Friends of a Feather
Description:
Four little birds are missing their tail feathers, and need your help to find them! Add feathers to your bird each turn by drawing from the deck, or trading away your unwanted feathers to the nest. Score points at the end of the game based on your colorful collection. The player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

Name: Mickey Mouse Snuggle Time
Description:
Snuggle up for a calming, co-operative game that's perfect for bedtime, nap time, or any quiet time. Help Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse, and their friends get the farm animals across the blanket game board and into the barn before the sun goes down.

To play Mickey Mouse Snuggle Time, lay out the board, turn the sun arrow to "nine", and place all five animals in the starting area. Each turn, a player spins a spinner, which will either move an animal or count down the sun arrow (in which case the player will spin again). When all animals have reached the barn, the game is over, and the sun arrow points at the players' final score.

—description from the publisher

Name: Orbita Victaris
Description:
Orbita Victaris is a tactical Science-Fiction/ Fantasy card game in which two or four players compete against each other on a shared battlefield.

VICTORY CONDITIONS
The player who has brought the shield points of his opponent to 0 wins or if the opponent can no longer draw cards (from his deck) or when a player gives up.

HOW TO PLAY
Each player starts with 6 shield points at the beginning of the game. These must be clearly visible to the opponentat all times (6-sided cube or by enclosed shield markers).

The maximum hand limit is 7. If a player has more than 7 cards in his hand at the end of their turn, they must place cards on their discard piles until the card limit is reached.

The card text always takes precedence over the rules in the rule book. This does not apply if the card text is incorrect.

Each turn consists of 5 phases, which are always traversed in this order of each move:

Start-phase:

In the initial phase, all effects that are activated by cards already in play at the beginning of the turn are resolved. The order in which the effects become active is determined by the active player. After all effects have been resolved with at the beginning, this phase ends and an action-event follows.

Draw-phase:

In this phase, the active player draws 1 card.

Recovering-phase:

All active player cards that are currently exausted (‘inactive’ on the side), with the exception of Nexus resources, are again recoverd (turned ‘active’ / upright).

Main-phase:

This phase represents the main part of a turn. In its main phase, a player may play cards from his hand, declare attacks, activate unit card effects on the field, or use his operator.

End-phase:

At the beginning of this phase, all effects are dealt with which explicitly occur at the end of the turn. This includes the removal of played command cards with the wording until the end of the turn. As in the initial phase, the active player, if relevant, determines the order of these steps. After that, the other player starts with his initial phase.

—description from the designer

Name: Greetings from Grandville
Description:
Welcome to Grandville, home of the Pizza Palace and the famous Golden Gopher!

Walk, bus, bike, or take the subway in a race around town to be the first to see the sights in Greetings from Grandville. There's more than one way to get where you're going, but you'll have to get there first to win.

With beginner and advance options, this game is a sightseeing adventure for the whole family!

—description from the publisher

Name: Cathracha
Description:
Cathracha is a skirmish/adventure board game for 1-8 players. In this deckbuilding board game, you travel around the cities of the magical island Tir na nOg. Collect weapons, gems and other items to become the strongest druid. Go for an "all against each other" battle, using magical weapons and items to be the last man standing! You can also play solo or with your friends on multiple campaigns, learning the deeper lore of Cathracha and face your enemies with your group of heroes.
Movement is done with a D12 die. Players move around the board, gather cards and attack each other. Players lose when they have lost all life points.

—description from the publisher
